summary: Prepare to suffer.
body:
Y'all are wearing that in Spider-Man far from home, Peter is going to be suffering PTSD and morning Tony who probably sacrificed himself so he and many others could live. But honestly, it’s much more likely that however Peter comes back, he won’t remember all the events that saved him or what happened before. It would work much better to retcon continuity for the future, if Peter didn’t remember Tony at all.

Prepare to suffer.

summary: Don't judge a book
title: Don't judge a book
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2xKqVrk

by S_Horne

“What?”

“Over there,” Chad said, pointing to the other side of the gym. “Oh, what was his name?”

“Nerd?”

Steve resisted rolling his eyes. The others around him all laughed as though that was the funniest joke they’d ever heard. Adam threw his arm over Steve’s shoulders and Steve resisted the urge to shrug him off.

“You remember him, right? God, he used to have such a crush on you. He’d follow you round after practice like a lost dog.”

/

Steve goes to his high-school reunion and has to manfully resist the urge to throat-punch a thousand people.

summary: Roots [COMING SOON]
title: Roots [COMING SOON]
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2QhaQQB

by paratoxic

Steve remembers how his whole world stopped turning when he heard the news that his boyfriend was killed. He remembers not leaving his house for weeks except to show up to Bucky’s funeral and watch the casket drop into the dirt. He remembers, most importantly, being forced to move on.

Years later, Steve is about to marry Tony and is digging through Bucky’s old possessions. The box he finds under the bed sends him right back to square one; it’s filled to the brim with fake IDs and abandoned credit cards, and one other thing.

A map.

[COMING SOON.]

summary:

Steve: I am going to do this, so maybe you're the one who should leave.

body:
Bucky: Just leave and let me have Tony.

Steve: I am going to do this, so maybe you’re the one who should leave.

Bucky: I’m not going anywhere.

Steve: Well, then, I guess you and I are walking into that bedroom together.

Bucky: I guess we are. I'mma walk.

Steve: So am I.

Bucky: Heading right for that bedroom.

Steve: Yup. Just making a b-line.

Bucky: You, me, Tony. That is three naked people.

Steve: And two of them are us.

summary:
slow dance 
an undertow cut scene
(spoilers for future chapters)
She decides she’ll be the first to say sorry, hours later when...
body:
slow dance

an undertow cut scene

(spoilers for future chapters)

She decides she’ll be the first to say sorry, hours later when she’s tired of being mad about it and her chest aches because she’d thrown his mother in his face. She really wasn’t playing fair. She’d been doing so much better and then…

Well, maybe he shouldn’t have said shit about her Baba’s apparent lack of strictness in parenting her, then. But even so, he’d been at least a little right. Baba had been nothing but lenient with her though he’d had a firm hand on T’Challa. She’d blame it on being the baby, the long awaited, much prayed for miracle that had come nearly a decade after her parents had married. She could probably blame it on how absolutely adorable she’d been, too, or how precocious, or simply because her parents had wanted a princess so badly they could taste it.

But she didn’t feel like blaming it anything at all except that she really needed to grow up and now. She was a mother, a wife, and had two little ones on the way. She couldn’t keep picking fights with her husband just because she was bored. And the first step in being a grownup was admitting that she was wrong. So, she sought him out to apologize, after Thandi had FaceTimed Jude and washed up and was tucked away, sleeping soundly in bed.

She finds him on the back porch, the screen open so that the early March air could come floating in to the kitchen. There were still clouds from the storm earlier, and no stars shone through and no moon. In the distance, she could just barely see the dark tree line and the lone light that was Bruce’s little cottage. Tony sat in the metal foldaway chair with a drink in one hand and his record player on the table beside him, and he hummed a bit under his breath, just a tad off key. For a second, she just stood in the doorway and watched him, took in the glimmer of silver in his dark hair, the lines on his face, the sensuality of his mouth. And she thought of how much she honestly loved this irascible, insufferable, annoying old man.

Bast, she loved him. It only seemed to grow more and more pronounced the closer she got to May and the birth of the twins.

“Are you gonna stand in the door all night, pretty baby?” he asks, his voice low and soft, and she knows from the tone that he’s not even close to being mad anymore. And that somehow makes her feel worse because he was always the one who caved first, who let go of his anger and conceded to her just to make things right.

I don’t wanna argue, he’d said. God only knows how much longer I’ve got left. But she’d gone and argued with him anyway, because what did American doctors know? And what was a little heart trouble to Wakandan medicine? Fuck whatever T’Challa said, she’d drag him into her old lab no matter what it cost her if it would save him.

Her Tony. She blinked back sorry, guilty tears at the thought of losing her Tony. But there was no use in worrying about that now. Worrying never solved anything. Shuri shook her head slightly to clear and moved out the doorway, wobbling a little in her slippers as the weight of her belly tilted her forward. She opened her mouth to say something, maybe an “I’m sorry” for starters, but couldn’t quite get it out. And he didn’t turn to look at her just yet, his whiskey still in hand and his eyes still on the misty, dark sky.

“What are you listening to?” she asks, matching his tone and keeping her voice low lest she wake Thandi or ruin the fragile peace that had been laid between the two of them. Whatever is playing, it’s something bluesy and upbeat and she watches as Tony’s feet taps in time with the melody.

“Bobby Womack,” he answers, and he clears his throat, takes a long swig. He waves her over toward him and she follows, catching his hand when he offers it and sliding into his lap with practiced ease. It’s a little different now that she’s so big and heavy but she manages, curling up against his chest like always. And the two of them don’t speak for a long while as the song plays, the only noise besides the music the sound of trucks on the highway in the far distance and the subtle drip drop of rain water from the gutters.

In the sweet quiet that surrounds them, she bites the bullet and gathers her courage, pushes her pride far as she can and sucks in a deep breath before she finally just says it.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know.”

“Do you?”

“Mmhm. Cause I am too.” He tilts her head up to look at him and she feels her heart pitter patter in her chest at the love in his eyes. She really doesn’t deserve him, she knows. But she’ll take all the good from him she can get. “I’d say ‘water under the bridge’ but…” But they needed to talk about her mouth and his temper and vice versa, so no water under the bridge. And that was good. She really didn’t want to just let that go. She wanted to work it out.

“Yeah. That was…cruel of me.”

Tony shrugs, as if it’s nothing though she knows that had hurt him worse than anything she may have done in the last few months had. She wouldn’t say years. She’d spent the first few years she knew him hurting him in ways that made her so ashamed now she rarely ever thought about them.

“It’s alright. I mean, it’s not alright, but it’s okay. We’ll talk about it later.” He sighs and kisses her temple, his lips warm and gentle on her skin. “Just sit here with me for a while, okay?”

“Okay.”

He goes back to humming again, his feet picking up the beat of the song as if it’d never stopped. His hands slide down her arm to her waist and hold her close, his fingers stroking her through the thin sweater she wore. The rhythm of his heartbeat and the warmth of his skin was enough that she figured she could go to sleep just like this, in his lap on the porch, except that he started to talk again and she found she wanted to listen. She loved his voice when it was deep and gritty and soaked with whiskey, and she smiled as the whiskers of his goatee brushed against her forehead.

“I was thinking.”

“Mmhm.”

“You and the kids could go back to Wakanda while I work on the add ons. Stay a few weeks, maybe a month or two. I know you miss home.”

Shuri raised a brow and shifted a little in his lap. She did miss home and more than she thought she ever would, but Tony had been cagey about her going too far ever since that year away. She couldn’t blame him, honestly. That had been really rotten of her to do. “You trust me enough to let me run off with your children like that?”

Tony smiled, though there was a hint of sadness behind it that made her chest clench. “I don’t know, though I want to try to. I wanna say I do already, but…you know, you could go home and decide you really don’t like living on a farm with my old white ass anymore.”

She snorts out a laugh and holds her belly as she does, rubbing the skin stretched taut like a balloon. “Oh, trust me, I wouldn’t have married you if that were the case.”

“Good. Cause I’m gonna need my very own nursemaid in about ten years or so-“

“Stop it, no you won’t.”

“Incontinence, memory loss, hell, I’ve already got arthritis. I probably won’t have any teeth either. You’ll have to go get my medications and hearing aids.”

“Shut up, Anthony,” she says, but there’s no barb behind it. Her laugh softens to a smile and she reaches up to tug at his long hair. It’s near to his shoulders now. He refuses to cut it, at least until Jude breaks down and finally wants to lop his off. Something about solidarity or whatever. The long hair was beautiful on him though. She really didn’t mind at all.

“As you wish, princess,” he says and he kisses her nose, then her lips, ever so slowly as if he’s afraid she’ll get angry at him for doing so. She hates that. She hates that she’s hurt him so that he’s still scared of being affectionate or holding her close without a split-second jerk reaction of running just in case.

Shuri decides, then and there, she won’t give him a reason to ever again.

She sinks into the kiss with a satisfied sigh and drags her fingers through his hair, pulling his head down so he can map a trail of wet, open mouthed caresses down her neck and throat. She thinks maybe she’s down for some makeup sex, especially with her hormones raring like they are, and almost tells him so, but the song in the background changes and Tony pauses, eyes opened and glancing up at his record player.

“Oh, fuck yes.”

“Huh?” She blinks in the dim porch light and then glances to her husband, who grins like a half-drunk cat. He probably is half drunk, she thinks, and she licks her lips, the taste of his Jim Beam lingering on her tongue.

“C’mon, Kitten. Get up and dance with me.”

Shuri makes a face and wiggles her feet. “Tony, I’m big as a rhinoceros. You really think I could manage dancing like this?” He nods and she can’t help but chuckle. “No, seriously. I’ll get up and tip over and you’ll have to catch me.”

“You’re really not that big, you know.” He taps her hip and she groans, but swings her legs over the side. If he wants to dance, she’ll at least attempt to. It’s a slower song, thank goodness, so all she’ll have to do is sway side to side until the song goes off. “I’m sure it’s huge to you considering you’re tiny by default, but nope, not too big.” He smiles when she grunts and gets off his lap, her hand coming to her back so she doesn’t lose her balance. “At least not to me.”

Slow dancing with her belly in the way proves to be a bit of a challenge so Tony suggests that he hold her from the back and oddly enough, that works just fine. It’s the same artist singing, the soul and blues coming through in the song so acutely it makes Shuri dizzy. And Tony keeps his movements smooth and easy, twirling her every once in a while for added measure, then pulling her right back into the warmth of his arms. He kisses the shell of her ear and smooths his hands across her belly, then dips his head to kiss her jaw as he sings along.

“You’re pushin’ my love a little bit too far…I don’t think you know, I don’t think you know how blessed you are.”

Shuri shoots him a glare when he twirls her again and doesn’t miss the smirk on his mouth. “Are you trying to send me a message?” she asks him, when he’s close by again and his laugh is rich, deep. It sparks a small flame in her that she knows if he stokes will be a raging wildfire in a few minutes time. Makeup sex is most definitely on the menu tonight.

“Mmm no. Just wanted to sing along. I love this song.”

“Uh huh.”

“Serious.”

She knows, by the way he laughs afterward, that he isn’t. But she doesn’t mind. Maybe she needs to be reminded. Shuri threads her fingers through his and ignores the swell in her ankles and the ache in her back and slow dances on the porch with her Tony as the clouds clear and the stars sparkle brightly in the night sky.

(spoilers for future chapters)

She decides she’ll be the first to say sorry, hours later when she’s tired of being mad about it and her chest aches because she’d thrown his mother in his face. She really wasn’t playing fair. She’d been doing so much better and then…

Well, maybe he shouldn’t have said shit about her Baba’s apparent lack of strictness in parenting her, then. But even so, he’d been at least a little right. Baba had been nothing but lenient with her though he’d had a firm hand on T’Challa. She’d blame it on being the baby, the long awaited, much prayed for miracle that had come nearly a decade after her parents had married. She could probably blame it on how absolutely adorable she’d been, too, or how precocious, or simply because her parents had wanted a princess so badly they could taste it.

But she didn’t feel like blaming it anything at all except that she really needed to grow up and now. She was a mother, a wife, and had two little ones on the way. She couldn’t keep picking fights with her husband just because she was bored. And the first step in being a grownup was admitting that she was wrong. So, she sought him out to apologize, after Thandi had FaceTimed Jude and washed up and was tucked away, sleeping soundly in bed.

She finds him on the back porch, the screen open so that the early March air could come floating in to the kitchen. There were still clouds from the storm earlier, and no stars shone through and no moon. In the distance, she could just barely see the dark tree line and the lone light that was Bruce’s little cottage. Tony sat in the metal foldaway chair with a drink in one hand and his record player on the table beside him, and he hummed a bit under his breath, just a tad off key. For a second, she just stood in the doorway and watched him, took in the glimmer of silver in his dark hair, the lines on his face, the sensuality of his mouth. And she thought of how much she honestly loved this irascible, insufferable, annoying old man.

Bast, she loved him. It only seemed to grow more and more pronounced the closer she got to May and the birth of the twins.

“Are you gonna stand in the door all night, pretty baby?” he asks, his voice low and soft, and she knows from the tone that he’s not even close to being mad anymore. And that somehow makes her feel worse because he was always the one who caved first, who let go of his anger and conceded to her just to make things right.

I don’t wanna argue, he’d said. God only knows how much longer I’ve got left. But she’d gone and argued with him anyway, because what did American doctors know? And what was a little heart trouble to Wakandan medicine? Fuck whatever T’Challa said, she’d drag him into her old lab no matter what it cost her if it would save him.

Her Tony. She blinked back sorry, guilty tears at the thought of losing her Tony. But there was no use in worrying about that now. Worrying never solved anything. Shuri shook her head slightly to clear and moved out the doorway, wobbling a little in her slippers as the weight of her belly tilted her forward. She opened her mouth to say something, maybe an “I’m sorry” for starters, but couldn’t quite get it out. And he didn’t turn to look at her just yet, his whiskey still in hand and his eyes still on the misty, dark sky.

“What are you listening to?” she asks, matching his tone and keeping her voice low lest she wake Thandi or ruin the fragile peace that had been laid between the two of them. Whatever is playing, it’s something bluesy and upbeat and she watches as Tony’s feet taps in time with the melody.

“Bobby Womack,” he answers, and he clears his throat, takes a long swig. He waves her over toward him and she follows, catching his hand when he offers it and sliding into his lap with practiced ease. It’s a little different now that she’s so big and heavy but she manages, curling up against his chest like always. And the two of them don’t speak for a long while as the song plays, the only noise besides the music the sound of trucks on the highway in the far distance and the subtle drip drop of rain water from the gutters.

In the sweet quiet that surrounds them, she bites the bullet and gathers her courage, pushes her pride far as she can and sucks in a deep breath before she finally just says it.

“I’m sorry.”

“I know.”

“Do you?”

“Mmhm. Cause I am too.” He tilts her head up to look at him and she feels her heart pitter patter in her chest at the love in his eyes. She really doesn’t deserve him, she knows. But she’ll take all the good from him she can get. “I’d say ‘water under the bridge’ but…” But they needed to talk about her mouth and his temper and vice versa, so no water under the bridge. And that was good. She really didn’t want to just let that go. She wanted to work it out.

“Yeah. That was…cruel of me.”

Tony shrugs, as if it’s nothing though she knows that had hurt him worse than anything she may have done in the last few months had. She wouldn’t say years. She’d spent the first few years she knew him hurting him in ways that made her so ashamed now she rarely ever thought about them.

“It’s alright. I mean, it’s not alright, but it’s okay. We’ll talk about it later.” He sighs and kisses her temple, his lips warm and gentle on her skin. “Just sit here with me for a while, okay?”

“Okay.”

He goes back to humming again, his feet picking up the beat of the song as if it’d never stopped. His hands slide down her arm to her waist and hold her close, his fingers stroking her through the thin sweater she wore. The rhythm of his heartbeat and the warmth of his skin was enough that she figured she could go to sleep just like this, in his lap on the porch, except that he started to talk again and she found she wanted to listen. She loved his voice when it was deep and gritty and soaked with whiskey, and she smiled as the whiskers of his goatee brushed against her forehead.

“I was thinking.”

“Mmhm.”

“You and the kids could go back to Wakanda while I work on the add ons. Stay a few weeks, maybe a month or two. I know you miss home.”

Shuri raised a brow and shifted a little in his lap. She did miss home and more than she thought she ever would, but Tony had been cagey about her going too far ever since that year away. She couldn’t blame him, honestly. That had been really rotten of her to do. “You trust me enough to let me run off with your children like that?”

Tony smiled, though there was a hint of sadness behind it that made her chest clench. “I don’t know, though I want to try to. I wanna say I do already, but…you know, you could go home and decide you really don’t like living on a farm with my old white ass anymore.”

She snorts out a laugh and holds her belly as she does, rubbing the skin stretched taut like a balloon. “Oh, trust me, I wouldn’t have married you if that were the case.”

“Good. Cause I’m gonna need my very own nursemaid in about ten years or so-“

“Stop it, no you won’t.”

“Incontinence, memory loss, hell, I’ve already got arthritis. I probably won’t have any teeth either. You’ll have to go get my medications and hearing aids.”

“Shut up, Anthony,” she says, but there’s no barb behind it. Her laugh softens to a smile and she reaches up to tug at his long hair. It’s near to his shoulders now. He refuses to cut it, at least until Jude breaks down and finally wants to lop his off. Something about solidarity or whatever. The long hair was beautiful on him though. She really didn’t mind at all.

“As you wish, princess,” he says and he kisses her nose, then her lips, ever so slowly as if he’s afraid she’ll get angry at him for doing so. She hates that. She hates that she’s hurt him so that he’s still scared of being affectionate or holding her close without a split-second jerk reaction of running just in case.

Shuri decides, then and there, she won’t give him a reason to ever again.

She sinks into the kiss with a satisfied sigh and drags her fingers through his hair, pulling his head down so he can map a trail of wet, open mouthed caresses down her neck and throat. She thinks maybe she’s down for some makeup sex, especially with her hormones raring like they are, and almost tells him so, but the song in the background changes and Tony pauses, eyes opened and glancing up at his record player.

“Oh, fuck yes.”

“Huh?” She blinks in the dim porch light and then glances to her husband, who grins like a half-drunk cat. He probably is half drunk, she thinks, and she licks her lips, the taste of his Jim Beam lingering on her tongue.

“C’mon, Kitten. Get up and dance with me.”

Shuri makes a face and wiggles her feet. “Tony, I’m big as a rhinoceros. You really think I could manage dancing like this?” He nods and she can’t help but chuckle. “No, seriously. I’ll get up and tip over and you’ll have to catch me.”

“You’re really not that big, you know.” He taps her hip and she groans, but swings her legs over the side. If he wants to dance, she’ll at least attempt to. It’s a slower song, thank goodness, so all she’ll have to do is sway side to side until the song goes off. “I’m sure it’s huge to you considering you’re tiny by default, but nope, not too big.” He smiles when she grunts and gets off his lap, her hand coming to her back so she doesn’t lose her balance. “At least not to me.”

Slow dancing with her belly in the way proves to be a bit of a challenge so Tony suggests that he hold her from the back and oddly enough, that works just fine. It’s the same artist singing, the soul and blues coming through in the song so acutely it makes Shuri dizzy. And Tony keeps his movements smooth and easy, twirling her every once in a while for added measure, then pulling her right back into the warmth of his arms. He kisses the shell of her ear and smooths his hands across her belly, then dips his head to kiss her jaw as he sings along.

“You’re pushin’ my love a little bit too far…I don’t think you know, I don’t think you know how blessed you are.”

Shuri shoots him a glare when he twirls her again and doesn’t miss the smirk on his mouth. “Are you trying to send me a message?” she asks him, when he’s close by again and his laugh is rich, deep. It sparks a small flame in her that she knows if he stokes will be a raging wildfire in a few minutes time. Makeup sex is most definitely on the menu tonight.

“Mmm no. Just wanted to sing along. I love this song.”

“Uh huh.”

“Serious.”

She knows, by the way he laughs afterward, that he isn’t. But she doesn’t mind. Maybe she needs to be reminded. Shuri threads her fingers through his and ignores the swell in her ankles and the ache in her back and slow dances on the porch with her Tony as the clouds clear and the stars sparkle brightly in the night sky.

body:
Peter: So I can either bake these cookies at 400 degrees for 10 minutes or 4,000 degrees for 1 minute.
Tony: Peter, NO THAT’S NOT HOW YOU BAKE COOKIES
Peter: FLOOR IT?
Tony: PETER NO
Peter: HOW ABOUT 4,000,000 DEGREES FOR 1 SECOND
Tony: PETER YOU ARE GOING TO BURN NEW YORK DOWN
Peter: I’M GOING TO HARNESS THE POWER OF THE FUCKING SUN TO MAKE COOKIES
Tony: PETER PLEASE
